title: Catherine Penaranda Escobar
text:
Catherine Penaranda Escobar


MBA Candidate | Strategic Thinker | Project Accelerator




I am currently pursuing my MBA in Vancouver, Canada, with a strong foundation in economics, public policy, and business strategy. With several years of experience in project management and stakeholder engagement, I specialize in analyzing economic trends, shaping strategic policies, and leading cross-functional teams.


My passion lies in contributing to purpose-driven organizations, particularly in the areas of consulting, sustainable development, and innovation. I believe in empowering decision-makers with actionable insights, and I’m eager to drive impact through thoughtful leadership and collaboration.


Mission: To become a strategic leader who bridges data, people, and policy to create solutions that improve lives and business outcomes.

title: PROFESSIONAL SUMMARY
text:
PROFESSIONAL SUMMARY
Results-driven professional with a strong background in economics, public policy, and business strategy. Experienced in project management and stakeholder engagement. Skilled in developing strategic policies and leading cross-functional teams. Currently pursuing an MBA to enhance leadership and marketing skills. Fluent in Spanish and English.



Professional Experience

Project Coordinator
Colombian Association of Oil and Gas, Bogota, Colombia. 2021 – 2024

Developed and implemented social and environmental projects in oil and gas regions.
Built relationships with stakeholders, government agencies, and private sector partners.
Managed project timelines, budgets, and risk assessments.



Specialized Professional
Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, Bogota, Colombia. 2013 – 2021

Designed and monitored public policies for agricultural finance and production chains.
Conducted economic research and policy assessments to support sustainable development.
Collaborated with cross-functional teams to implement regulatory frameworks.





Education

MBA Candidate, University Canada West, Vancouver, Canada. (2024 – Present)
Master of Public Policy in Economics, Universidad del Rosario, Bogota, Colombia. (2018 – 2021)
Specialist in Public Policy Analysis, Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogota, Colombia. (2013 – 2014)
Economist, Escuela Colombiana de Ingeniería “Julio Garavito”, Bogota, Colombia. (2007 – 2012)

title: Projects
text:
Source: ACP

With the aim of strengthening the skills of public servants and the community in Puerto Wilches – Santander for the implementation, control, and monitoring of projects carried out through the General System of Royalties, ExxonMobil donated $3,000 USD to the Colombian Oil and Gas Association (ACP). The purpose was to offer a training process to improve understanding of the SGR by teaching basic concepts and key aspects related to the design of royalty-funded projects, as well as developing skills for tracking the use of these resources.
In collaboration with the Fundación Universitaria del Área Andina, the diploma course “General System of Royalties and Project Design for Social and Community Development” was delivered in person in Puerto Wilches. The course included a total of 120 hours of work, divided into 10 in-person sessions, and was aimed at a group of 30 participants made up of public officials from the municipality and community members.

title: Projects
text:
Empowering Women in Puerto Wilches


Source: ACP

As part of its Women’s Economic Opportunities initiative, ExxonMobil supported leadership development, business knowledge, and planning tools to help women create microenterprises and generate income for themselves and their communities. In 2023, ExxonMobil donated 23,000 USD to the Colombian Oil and Gas Association (ACP) to continue supporting 20 women from Puerto Wilches in their journey toward economic empowerment.
The ACP carried out the program in two phases. The first, in partnership with Mujeres Oil & Gas, included a motivational workshop titled “No Obstacle Can Stop a Brave Heart,” focused on boosting self-confidence and leadership. The second phase offered training to strengthen their businesses through economic and financial education. These actions helped the women improve their entrepreneurial skills and advance their financial independence.
